keywords: Lahontan Cutthroat Trout, Omak Lake, water quality, fish survival, saltwater transition feed, post-stocking survival, hatchery reared fish.

abstract:
This study aims to investigate the effect of a saltwater transition feed diet on the post-stocking survival of juvenile Lahontan Cutthroat Trout in Omak Lake. The lake is known for its unique environment with higher pH and total dissolved solids levels, which may be challenging for the trout.

Given that natural reproduction does not occur in Omak Lake, annual stocking is essential to maintain the fishery. However, survival rates have been very low (only 1%), necessitating a search for potential solutions. One suggested approach is introducing a saltwater transition feed diet, which has shown promise based on prior research and understanding of the Lahontan Cutthroat Trout's evolutionary history.

To test this hypothesis, an experiment will be carried out following these steps:
1. Obtain a sufficient number of juvenile Lahontan Cutthroat Trout from a hatchery.
2. Randomly divide the fish into two groups: a control group (given a standard feed) and an experimental group (receiving a saltwater transition feed).
3. Release both groups in Omak Lake following normal stocking procedures.
4. Monitor the survival rates of both groups over a specific period (e.g., several months).
5. Compare the survival rates between the control and experimental groups to determine if there is any significant difference.

This experiment is crucial as it provides valuable insight into whether a saltwater transition feed can improve post-stocking survival in this specific environment. If successful, this research could lead to more effective stocking practices, benefiting the Omak Lake fishery and potentially other similar fisheries with unique environmental conditions.

description:
This text focuses on the survival challenges of Lahontan Cutthroat Trout (Oncorhynchus clarkii henshawii) in Omak Lake, a man-made fishery where natural reproduction is absent and annual stocking is required. The text highlights the unique environmental requirements of Lahontan Cutthroat Trout with respect to higher pH and total dissolved solids levels compared to other salmonid species.

The authors discuss a pilot study reporting poor (1%) post-stocking survival, prompting research into improving survival rates using dietary interventions, specifically a saltwater transition feed. The subsequent section outlines an experimental procedure aimed at investigating the impact of this saltwater transition feed on juvenile Lahontan Cutthroat Trout survival.

Firstly, hatchery-reared fish will be acclimated to the test water conditions for a week prior to feeding the experimental diet. The test water conditions mimic those found in Omak Lake – pH and total dissolved solids levels – to ensure fish experience the environmental stressors they encounter post-stocking.

Secondly, juvenile Lahontan Cutthroat Trout will be randomly divided into control and experimental groups. The control group will continue receiving their standard hatchery feed, while the experimental group will be fed a saltwater transition feed during the two weeks prior to stocking in Omak Lake.

Thirdly, following the feeding period, both groups of fish will undergo handling stress prior to being released into the lake. This stress is intentional and mimics the conditions they would experience post-stocking.

Fourthly, survival rates will be compared between control and experimental groups after one month post-stocking using mark-recapture techniques. The study will measure the percentage of stocked fish surviving to assess the effectiveness of the saltwater transition feed in improving post-stocking survival.

The experimental setup seeks to determine whether a dietary intervention, in this case the use of a saltwater transition feed, can improve the post-stocking survival of juvenile Lahontan Cutthroat Trout by mitigating the environmental stressors they face upon introduction into Omak Lake.

target: Investigating saltwater feed impact on Lahontan Cutthroat Trout survival.

constraints:
The text discusses a study on improving the post-stocking survival of Lahontan Cutthroat Trout in Omak Lake through the use of a saltwater transition feed diet. Here are some potential constraints mentioned in the method and where they appear in the text:

1. **Fish species**: The study focuses specifically on Lahontan Cutthroat Trout (Oncorhynchus clarkii henshawi). (Mentioned throughout the text)
2. **Water quality**: The text mentions that Omak Lake has higher pH and total dissolved solids levels compared to other salmonid environments, which may impact water quality for the fish. (Mentioned in "Lahontan Cutthroat Trout have evolved to inhabit lakes with higher pH and total dissolved solids levels.")
3. **Acclimation to the stocking environment**: The text states that natural reproduction does not occur in Omak Lake, and fish must be stocked annually. (Mentioned in "As natural reproduction does not occur in the lake, fish must be stocked annually in order to maintain the fishery.")
4. **Post-stocking survival**: The study aims to improve post-stocking survival of juvenile Lahontan Cutthroat Trout by testing a saltwater transition feed diet. (Mentioned throughout the text)
5. **Saltwater transition feed**: The experiment tests the effects of a saltwater transition feed diet on post-stocking survival. (Mentioned in "In order to improve post-stocking survival, a saltwater transition feed for hatchery reared fish has been suggested.")

No code is provided in the text.
